properties.name: Baptiste Power Yoga
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing  2000 Massachusetts Ave, Cambridge, MA (617 661 YOGA)Vinyasa power yoga in room heated to 90 degrees F. This was my first yoga experience and I really enjoyed it. The level of new-age bla bla you get here depends on the instructor. Bring your own towel. They use too much bleach on their towels and the smell of chlorine is pretty unpleasant. Don\'t forget water. You\'re going to need it. If they had showers, it would be a really great place to go for yoga, but instead you have to leave the place pretty much dripping in your own sweat, which is especially a drag in the freezing cold months.

properties.name: Calumet Photographic
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing65 Bent Street cambridge maVery good photo supply store. They don\'t do any development in-house, but they have a lot of nice equipment.

properties.name: Cambridgeside Galleria (Apple Store)
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing100 Cambridgeside Place, Cambridge, MA, 02141

properties.name: Centro Presente/Pintamos Nuestro Mundo
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing54 Essex Street, Cambridge, MA617-497-9080 x30 cynthiaatcentro@yahoo.com This bilingual after-school public arts and leadership project brings together Somerville Latino youth 11-15 years old. The project takes place in the Somerville Youth Center on the corner of Cross Street and Broadway in East Somerville. Volunteers and mentors are welcome.

properties.name: Goodwill
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing   230 Elm St, Somerville, MA 02144This is one of the best Goodwill stores I have ever know. It is huge. It is friendly. The people who run it are really nice and the people who work there are friendly and don\'t seem to hate their jobs passionately as is sometimes the case in a Goodwill or Salvation Army. Every once in a while I get a lucky yarn score here, though rarely do I see needles.

properties.name: Grub Street Writers,Inc.
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing561 Windsor Street Somerville, MARon MacLean 617-623-8100 info@grubstreet.org As Boston\'s only private writing school Grub Street Writers is dedicated to providing the community with first-rate writing workshops--workshops that are fun down-to-earth and at the same time disciplined and serious. They offer beginning and advanced workshops in fiction, poetry, creative nonfiction playwriting sitcom writing and screenwriting.

properties.name: Mind's Eye
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing  This convenient store is on the ground floor of a pink house right across from the parking lot of the Porter Square mall with the Stop and Shop. It took me a while to notice it was a knitting store. That weird little street along the parking lot has a sort of no-man\'s land feeling to it. The woman who owns the store is helpful. She has a lot of spinning supplies and it seems like a good place to go if you want to get into spinning. She only seems to sell wooden needles, which I don\'t care for. Very few books, but the Porter Square Bookstore across the lot has a good knitting section. She usually has some nutty novelty yarns in her sale basket.

properties.name: O2 Yoga
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing  288 Highland Avenue, Somerville, MA. (617.625.0267)They don\'t have many really early classes, but they do have a weekly class in Spanish. I like their motto: "Up dogs. Down dogs. No dogma."

properties.name: Old Round House
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing This round house was recently bought and it is going to be renovated, according to rumor. It is very delapidated. from wikipedia: It was built in 1856 by hardware manufacturer Enoch Robinson, and is considered an offshoot of the Octagon House style popularized by phrenologist Orson Fowler. More information from Culture Junkie

properties.name: Porter Square Books, Very Nice Bookstore and Cafe
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing 25 White St, Cambridge, MAThey will give you the pass for free wifi if it isn\'t too crazy crowdy in there.

properties.name: Sad Flag vs Happy Flag
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishingWe noticed these two flags on homes directly facing one another and couldn\'t help but wonder if they might be symbols of some kind of bigger neighborly dichotomy. Happy Flag Happy Flag lives at the tip top of his very own, real-life, free-standing flagpole. He waves proudly from the corner of Harvard Place and Harvard Street. His house has columns on its front porch! Sad Flag Sad flag lies tangled around its pathetic, fallen, cheap-ass broomstick of a flag pole, supported by a grimy old pvc awning over a modest stoop.

properties.name: Spark Craft Studios
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing1963 Massachusetts Avenue, Cambridge, MASpark fills many crafty needs, but their knitting stuff is on the lower level. They have a few books and magazines, a limited range of needles, and lovely high-end (expensive) yarns. They have a drop-in crafting membership which I\'ve never tried, but my knitting gang had a really fun time one night hanging out there knitting as a free trial. The renovation of the building is totally beautiful. They sell some local designers\' wares. They have TONS of scrapbooking stuff.

properties.name: Target
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing180 Somerville Ave, Somerville, MA

properties.name: The Healey School
properties.description: Posted by Tracy_the_astonishing 5 Meacham St Somerville, MA 02145
